title: Dow jumps over 400 points as investors assess Russia-Ukraine talks, await Fed meeting
text:
What's happening?

The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA was up around 400 points, or 1.2%, at 33,346.

The S&P 500 SPX rose 39 points, or 0.9%, to 4,243.

The Nasdaq Composite COMP erased an early stumble and was edging higher, up 0.3%, picking up 45 points, at around 12,889.

The Dow fell 2% last week for its fifth straight weekly decline, while the S&P 500 has dropped four of the last five weeks and is down 12% from its record close established just after the new year.

Read:‘Unprecedented territory': Stocks slump on Russia-Ukraine war as jittery investors watch for Fed to start hiking rates amid high market volatility

What's driving markets?

A fourth round of talks between Ukraine and Russia were being held, after a weekend in which Russia pounded a military training base near the border with Poland, killing at least 35 people. Russia continued its offensive on Monday throughout Ukraine.

“Financial markets have turned into one gigantic ‘war trade' in recent weeks. Politics has overshadowed economics, with most assets driven entirely by the conflict in Ukraine,” said Marios Hadjikyriacos, senior market analyst at XM, in a note.

“This phenomenon is on full display today after negotiators on both sides signaled progress in the latest peace talks and kept the door open for a cease-fire soon,” the analyst wrote.

U.S. and Chinese security officials were meeting in Rome on Monday as the U.S. alleged that Russia was seeking military equipment from the world's number-two economy.

Meanwhile, the head of the International Monetary Fund said Sunday that she expects a “deep recession” in Russia due to “unprecedented” sanctions by the West after its invasion of Ukraine, and that a Russian sovereign default remains a possibility.

In an interview with CBS News' “Face the Nation,” IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said that she no longer saw a Russian debt default as an “improbable event.”

China, separately, locked down the key southeastern manufacturing hub of Shenzhen as it also combats a COVID outbreak in the northeast of the country. The Hang Seng HK: HSI slumped 5% and the Shanghai Composite CN: SHCOMP fell nearly 3%.

The Chinese lockdowns have the potential to further exacerbate supply-chain woes with inflation already running at nearly 8%.

The backdrop of uncertainties has forced strategists to lower their outlook for equities. Those at Goldman Sachs lowered their year-end price target to 4,700 from 4,900, citing the surge in commodities prices and the weaker outlook for U.S. and global growth. Goldman's economists on Friday had cut their GDP forecast and said the odds of a U.S. recession next year were as high as 35%.

Another important event is the U.S. central bank's policy gathering, set to kick off on Tuesday. The Federal Reserve on Wednesday is expected to make its first interest-rate hike in years in response to the surge in inflation.

Ahead of that decision, government debt was selling off, with the yield on the benchmark 10-year note BX: TMUBMUSD10Y yielding 2.10%.

Which companies are in focus?

IEP Utility Holdings LLC, a unit of Icahn Enterprises LP, is raising the tender offer price for Southwest Gas Holdings Inc. SWX to $82.50 a share in cash from a previous price of $75 a share. Southwest Gas shares were up 3.6% near $75.21 a share.

U.S.-listed shares of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. BABA sank 6.8% as the China-based e-commerce giant continues to suffer from a broad selloff in China's stock market, amid the threat of delisting of shares of China-based companies in the U.S. 

What are other assets doing?

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, was down 0.3%.

Oil futures retreated, with the U.S. benchmark CL.1 down 7.7% at $100.94 a barrel. Gold futures GC00 fell 1.4% to $1,957.60 an ounce.

Bitcoin BTCUSD rose 3% to around $39,000.

The Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP rose 1.4%, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX gained 0.6%.

—Steve Goldstein contributed to this article.
